Award.AwardTitle: Dissertation Research: Resolving bipolar phylogeographic histories in dispersal limited mosses: a RAD-Seq approach
Award.AbstractNarration:
The geographic distribution of many plants is shaped by long distance dispersal (LDD) across oceans and unsuitable habitats, typically by wind currents. Geographic distributions that do not correlate with wind paths and the occurrence of widely distributed species not suited for wind dispersal suggests, however, that dispersal may be accomplished by other means, such as by migratory birds. Our knowledge of LDD and thus its affect on shaping global floristic diversity is limited to model cases where wind paths are available for organisms with high dispersal ability. Lewis and Goffinet will use revolutionary genome sequencing techniques, to reconstruct non-model global dispersal histories and assess the frequency and significance of these events on the biodiversity of pristine high latitude regions.

Understanding the processes that shape biodiversity allow us to better understand how the ecosystems we know have come to be, and how they may change. High latitude regions represent some of the world?s most pristine ecosystems, but also the most vulnerable ones to global climate change. In conjunction with the Cape Horn Biosphere Reserve of Southernmost Chile, Lewis and Goffinet are integrating scientific investigation, in-situ conservation, community education, and ecotourism to introduce the public to high latitude bryophyte diversity and contribute to our understanding of these organisms, their ecosystems, and global plant dispersal.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Since the days of Darwin, explorers and scientists have pondered the global distribution of life. Many organisms, especially plants have discontinuous ranges, sometimes spanning multiple continents. One of the most extreme patterns is the bipolar or amphitropical distribution, where a species is reported to occur in the temperate, sub-polar to polar regions of both the Northern and Southern Hemispheres, but nowhere in between. The bipolar distribution characterizes many single celled organisms, but also complex ones from across the fungal, animal and plant kingdoms, but is most commonly associated with mosses (plants) and lichens (fungi). 

The common dung moss Tetraplodon dispersed from the Northern Hemisphere to subantarctic Chile approximately 8.63 million years ago. Southern populations are today recognized as the distinct species, T. fuegianus, only known from the southernmost South America. Previous work by the project investigators unambiguously identified long distance dispersal as the process that resulted in the origin of the American subantarctic endemic T. fuegianus, but traditional genetic tools were unable to provide the information necessary to determine from where in the Northern Hemisphere the ancestor of T. fuegianus dispersed. In order to resolve the biogeographic history of T. fuegianus, additional markers were deemed necessary. 

Restriction site associated DNA (RAD) sequencing, which allows for the sampling of thousands of genetic markers across populations for non-model organisms, was applied for the first time at a global phylogeographic scale. Over 4,000 RAD sites were identified and sequenced across 81 populations of the bipolar Tetraplodon lineage containing T. fuegianus. Inferences of historical events from these data confirmed the unique evolutionary identity of T. fuegianus, and revealed Northwestern North America as the ancestral source for southern South American populations. Furthermore, the analyses uncovered an unprecedented geographic structure among populations scattered across the Northern Hemisphere suggesting a complex history shaped by the glacial and interglacial periods of the Pleistocene. 

Future application of RADseq to phylogeography will likely allow for the discovery of genetic structure across ranges that have been believed to be homogeneous due to insufficient genetic information. This study demonstrates the value of RAD sequencing in revealing species migration patterns and genetic structure indicative of responses to past climatic changes in groups for which a lack of informative genetic markers has precluded meaningful historical inferences. 

Despite a high representation of mosses in the American temperate to polar floras, relatively little work has been done to reveal the processes shaping diversity in this group. The data generated by this study represents the most extensive population data set for any moss to date. RAD sequencing has been demonstrated to be a powerful tool for large-scale phylogeographic studies, and this project has created basic infrastructure for the broader application of this method at the University of Connecticut. Through the innovative Ecotourism with a hand lens program in subantarctic Chile, the results of this research are transformed into a narrative that is shared with visitors to the region, emphasizing the unique evolutionary history of one of the regions endemic species.
